title: Power to girls writing scripts for the future
text:
Voices Power to girls writing scripts for the future

Friday was International Day of the Girl Child, so there were lots of uplifting stories about girls overcoming obstacles to succeed and thrive. Of course, most of those obstacles are put there by their own relatives, their communities’ ignorant belief systems and by society enabling exploitative cultural practices.

Which is why this story of a boarding school is so compelling. Not any boarding school, but one in Kakuma refugee camp in Kenya, where three young women – Umohoza Hurlarain, Nyamam Gai Gatluak – and Mumina Khalif, were given the opportunity to go to school. They are among those who lead and force change – like their sisters in the environmental movement.

The trio were among the lucky 60 of 500 who vied for places at the camp’s one boarding school for girls, Angelina Jolie Primary School. The three and their fellow pupils are now safe and will be enabled to reach their potential.

according to a Unicef report entitled A Familiar Face: Violence in the Lives of Children and Adolescents, the dangers to too many children – and predominantly girls – are at home.

Nyamam says: “Those who make it to school, when they come home, they have to leave the books and go to the kitchen to cook and do chores because boys don’t do such work. So the girls don’t get time to study. Being in a boarding school is a privilege.”



Sexist chores are the least of it – according to a Unicef report entitled A Familiar Face: Violence in the Lives of Children and Adolescents, the dangers to too many children – and predominantly girls – are at home. The study looked at children’s experience of violence in 30 countries and found that three in four children aged two to four worldwide regularly experience violent discipline by their caregivers. About six in 10 are punished by physical means. Perhaps even more terrifying worldwide, one in four children under the age of five live with a mother who is a victim of intimate partner violence.

The theme for the day this year was Girlforce: Unscripted and Unstoppable. The unscripted is true in so many places, where 12 million girls are married before they are 18; 130 million girls do not go to school; and 15 million girls between the ages of 15 and 19 experience “forced sex” – which is rape.

Where relatives, communities and societies continue to deny the full and equal rights of girls and women, young women like Nyamam and her friends will write the script: “We want to work together when we grow up to make learning easier for girls.”

The emancipation of women and girls is unstoppable and stories like these remind us to drown out the drone of the dying patriarchy and remember that the future is female. It’s inevitable.
